utterance: Gabriela Schlau-Cohen: I would just add on to that. I think there are two fundamental problems. One is the hidden variables problem which is what Masha brought up and then the second is a synchronization problem. So if you're measuring dynamics, if you can't control the synchronization, the cell is controlling it, you are inherently averaging over many stages of the enzymatic cycle.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding and elaborating on existing ideas by discussing two fundamental problems related to measuring dynamics in cells.

utterance: Neil Kelleher: So does does a single molecule approaches could does that change the synchronization calculus?

utterance: Gabriela Schlau-Cohen: Well the problem is that I think again we get back to a tool problem. With the single molecule aspect, you don't have the spatial resolution. If you're using an optical readout, you're essentially limited to the point spread function which is several hundred nanometers, the fundamental limit of light. And then there are some ways to get around that but those are very challenging to work with in sort of warm, wet, and noisy biological systems.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on existing ideas through reasoning and providing details about the limitations of single molecule approaches.

utterance: Gabriela Schlau-Cohen: So here's the fundamental thing. Those sorts of single molecule those sorts of approaches are structural. It looks at sort of slow structural rearrangements by building up a reconstruction.

annotations.develop idea: Gabriela is expanding on her previous thoughts and providing more details about the limitations of single-molecule approaches.

utterance: Neel Shah: Could I I wanted to jump on that you know so when in in the kinase field there's a lot of I mean as Tania pointed out it's a well-studied class of proteins and so people have developed these really phenomenal biosensors right they're proteins usually based on two fluorescent proteins that undergo some sort of change in FRET intensity as a function of the kinase phosphorylating that that sensor. And what I've and I think they're great because you know you can see some sort of FRET signal change throughout the cell as a function of space and time and but those are not the endogenous substrates of that kinase right? And so I I often find myself wondering whether we miss something about the specific product that yields some functional outcome for the cell and whether that's being phosphorylated at the same sort of like time and in the same space that these sensors are. Because you see an uptake in the actual intrinsic activity of the enzyme somewhere at some point in time is that really where functional outcomes are produced in the cell? I think that's a big open question. And so we can map in optics and enzyme activity but if if the substrates that ultimately produce a phenotype are not there what like it doesn't matter right? And so I think like an ideal sensor would be one that is effectively on the endogenous product or is the endogenous product and somehow you'd be able to visualize that product forming the true product forming as a as a function of whatever parameters you're interested in which which I appreciate is like a tall order and that's the point of this conversation but yeah.

utterance: Wenjing Wang: Yeah, I also just want to add to what Nia just mentioned. So it is sometimes it is important maybe to only look at the substrate, the product. So that's why we have these in vitro method and in vivo method. Even for in vivo method for one enzyme, so you want to study the substrate input and the enzyme itself and its product, and product is affecting even like downstream enzyme or other proteins. So the nice thing is I guess it's possible to develop a sensor or method for at each step or each level and then so we cannot in the end eventually possibly we can combine all these views together and to have a more complete holistic picture of the whole process. Like for the problem I'm studying GPCR signaling, so we need to study when the ligand for GPCR is being released, time and space is important, and the GPCR itself whether it responds to it because whether the concentration is right or not. So you not only need to look at the ligand, you also need to look at the GPCR, and then once it's being activated and then its own post-translational modifications and it affects G proteins and downstream like secondary messenger effects. So all the good thing is there are people designing sensors for like each step of this process that I guess enable to to study like all of these together.

utterance: Neel Shah: Yeah I I just I I keep coming back to what Wenjing said earlier on about really making a series of measurements that probe different aspects of an enzyme's function and then basically figuring out how to integrate them. And so like from my perspective as somebody who studies kinases and phosphatases, I would want to be able to say over the course of some cellular process, can I do one experiment where I measure you know subcellular localization as a function of that process, another where I overlay on top of that intrinsic enzyme activity as a function of that same process, right, which may not necessarily be correlated because in some locale maybe the enzyme's inhibited or whatever, right? And then um so that second thing may come from like a product producing biosensor or something like that. And then the third thing might be mapping uh what it's interacting with as a function of you know space and time. And so whether that's products or that are being formed, other substrates that are being acted upon, or uh regulatory proteins or something. If you had those three pieces of measurement um over the same like sort of biological process, I think you could learn an enormous amount about what um that enzyme is actually doing and how it operates. And then the fourth kind of dream thing would be to be able to map onto that the conformational dynamics of the protein as a function of all these things but uh and that's something as a structural biologist I would love to be able to do but um you know we wear different hats in our lab so um yeah I I none of those are a proposal for a specific technology but if there are four technologies that we could merge into one thing, that would be like for example if I was going to pitch a project to this group, that's what I would pitch and I would just pitch my favorite enzyme because it would help us out. Um but yeah, that's my thought.

utterance: Masha Kamenetska: several thoughts. So first I just want to say I think some of what we were talking about before this last comment by Neel could be called chemical imaging or has been called by other people and where you have atomic scale resolution so you're imaging specific bonds and I don't know of a technique that can do that label-free or on small number of molecules right that's that's the challenge. So you can do chemical imaging but you need a lot of the same number of molecules so that you have high signal. If you have a very heterogeneous environment like the cell with it's you know that's harder to do and then you need a probe but then you need to get the probe into the cell so that's the challenge. But I also had another thought so I hope it's okay I'm totally changing direction. So you know in some sense we want kind of cellular or sorry atomic resolution or molecular resolution be able to to tell structure of individual molecules within the cell. On the other hand fundamentally I think processes within cells must be stochastic so that many random events are happening at once and not each of those events is meaningful right maybe it's binding non-specifically. So in that sense we actually want to be able to probe many different molecules so that we can see what the average behavior is. So it just something that came to mind maybe it's obvious to people who regularly think about biological processes but you know that's kind of a dichotomy just mapping what one individual molecule is doing for some very small amount of time may not give you an actually true any sort of information it might just be random.
